name: Swordflight Rogue, aiming to complete build circa lvl27 (before last chapter), DnD Hardcore rules

We are looking at something like Fighter 4, SD 1 and the rest in Rogue. Any thoughts and suggestions are welcome.

Early in Chapter II he gets HiPS, Exotic Weapon Proficiency and dual wield capacity. He begins Chapter III with having WF, IC and WS in Kukris. Immediate Epic feat picks are EWF, EWS and Epic Prowess.

My main issues are,

1) I have nowhere to squeeze Blind Fight in
2) The lack of attack feats such as Knockdown / Disarm / Called Shot
3) No ITWF



Peace

posts.author: Cenerae
posts.content: At a glance, you can only take weapon spec on a fighter level, starting at fighter 4 and beyond. You can't take weapon finesse at 1 rogue, it has to come at level 3 (at the earliest) unless you begin as a fighter.

posts.author: Luj1
posts.content:

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Sorry, Luj1, but I've moved this to the Build Request forum. Two reasons: first, much as the level 40, 20 and Free Level forums, the level 30 one is for fully tested builds; and second, you stand more chance of getting helpful input if it sits here, at least for now.

Also, given that the plan is for Swordflight to finish with a level 40 character, you might want to think about a build that goes all the way, rather than having to reconstruct or wing it. Just a thought.

Cheers

Hey no worries. As for max level, one should finish Ch4 at approx level 33 (confirmed by the creator of the module and Lilura).

posts.author: Luj1
posts.content: I do want to complete the build at around 27 though (beginning of Ch4) as to give me some flexibility

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
That's fair enough, it's just that Rogueknight has said he's looking at a six or seven part final product. Given that part 4 is already out, we're looking at maybe another 3-4 years before the whole beastie is complete, which admittedly would be a long wait to finalize your build. No problem at all with flexibility, except that building to level x might sometimes gimp its future development. Still, your call my friend!

Your build itself has sound principles, but has some issues. I'll have a proper look tomorrow if you'd like (It's 2.50 am for me atm) - though someone else may well come up with help and guidance before then.

Cheers

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
My big suggestion, for now would be to go

1- Rogue 1  - Dodge
2- Fighter 1 - Weapon Finesse
3- Fighter 2 - Weapon Proficiency Exotic, Weapon Focus: Kukri
4- Rogue 2
5- Rogue 3

The Fighter 1 level at level 2 grants you a lot of proficiencies, most notable being Shield Proficiency to equip a large shield with your shortsword, also extra HP and +2-3 Fort save early on. The extra AC from the large shield HP and fort save will help immensely if you plan to melee at level 2, and you will not have great AB for dual wielding anyway (not yet at least).

That being said, I have not yet played Swordflight which has a reputation of being difficult. 
If you do not think you will be able to melee at level 2, then you could go Rogue 2-3 at levels 2-3 instead before taking Fighter 1-2. 
Trouble is, sometimes the module will not let you have a choice.

Stag (the boss here) has promised to have a look and I am interested in what his thoughts would be (I am learning too!) so I am going to refrain from commenting further :)

Hope that helps!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content: I look at the skills list and find no detection skills other than  search. I would not build this kind of character without either listen or spot. Going rogue heavy and with Int 14, you should have sufficient skill points.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Listen to Mick.

He knows things.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Okay, I've got a draft for you, Luj. As I'm sure you appreciate, everything comes at a price, and here the cost is not taking SD until epic levels, a loss of skill points, and a diminution of sneak attack potency. What you get, however, is your full wish-list of feats, a marginally higher AB, and Epic Dodge. I restricted myself to your original stat distribution and the three classes you chose. I've tried to max its potency to level 27 while hopefully making it playable at all levels. However, I can't promise it's perfect, and others may well have ideas, but at the final analysis, it's about whether you feel comfortable with it.

Right, that's the disclaimers out of the way, so here's my first draft:

Rogue 14/ Fighter 12/ SD 1
Any alignment (I assume you have your own reasons for choosing evil)
Halfling
Level 1-27, PvM

Stats
STR 10
DEX 20 (26)
CON 12
WIS 8
INT 14
CHA 8

Hit Points: 239
AC: (naked) 25 (haven't done any other calculations yet)
Saves: Fort 15, Will 9 (horrible but inevitable), Reflex 22. +2 vs Fear spells, +3 vs spells (and some other stuff I haven't counted yet)
Spells: UMD
BAB: 21
AB: (4 APR, 6 when D-W) melee (max) 34 (32 when D-W); ranged (max) 30 (31 with sling, etc)
Sneak Attack: 7d6
HiPS
Epic Dodge
Skill Points: 226. (not done full breakdown yet, so this is a guide atm, and consists of inputted ranks) Tumble 30, Hide 30, MS 30, UMD 30, Listen or Spot 30, Spellcraft (cc) 13. 50 spare to distribute between Search, Open Lock, Disable and Set Trap

Levelling
1 R1: Dodge
2 R2: (Evasion)
3 F1: Weapon Proficiency: Exotic/ Weapon Finesse
4 F2: Weapon Focus: Kukri/ Dex+1 (21)
5 F3
6 F4: Weapon Specialization: Kukri/ Blind Fight
7 R3: (Uncanny Dodge I)
8 R4: Dex+1 (22)
9 R5: Knockdown
10 F5
11 F6: Improved Knockdown
12 R6: Two-Weapon Fighting/ Dex+1 (23)
13 R7
14 F7
15 F8: Ambidexterity/ Imp Two-Weapon Fighting
16 F9: Dex+1 (24)
17 R8
18 R9: Mobility
19 F10: Improved Critical: Kukri
20 R10: Dex+1 (25)/ (Improved Evasion)
21 SD1: Epic Weapon Focus: Kukri/ (HiPS)
22 R11
23 R12
24 F11: Epic Prowess (or Armour Skin for -1AB and +2AC)/ Dex+1 (26)
25 F12: Epic Weapon Specialization: Kukri
26 R13: (Defensive Roll)
27 R14: Epic Dodge

Over to you (and others) for thoughts and or laughter/derision.

Cheers

EDIT: I still do all this stuff on paper, so you'll have to forgive me if some of my sums are a bit shonky.

posts.content:
I will refer you to Web's comment: Mick knows things (and he tests his builds in Swordflight currently). The one skill that baffles me is Persuade. Unless you can tell me otherwise, it's a "nice to have" not a "must have", whereas detecting enemies is definitely a "must have".

Cheers

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
I'm hearing you want to keep persuade, I can make suggestions to try to save persuade if you like.

I know the NWN system well, but am blind to the Swordfight environment, and apologise in advance if some of these suggestions are no good.

There is no practical difference between modified Set Trap 15 and 44 if:
1. you use only deadly traps or lesser (excluding deadly gas traps). 
2. you only set traps outside of combat (for Take 20) or have Skill Mastery (for automatic Take 20 during combat)

This is usually my situation. I find gas traps of little use personally, and prefer the others (Fire/Electrical/Tangle/Holy/Sonic/Frost/Negative). I generally only set traps outside of combat. It makes sense to take Skill Mastery if you want to set them during combat, it will also help with opening locks and retrieving/disabling traps too.

Either way you get a pile of skill points if you do that for a dex build, you might only need 5-8 ranks in set trap to get to modified set trap 15.

If you want to set Epic Traps, you will require Set Trap 45 modified which seems hard to obtain in a level 27-28 build. 
I do not know the environment well enough if that is worth the investment but it seems unlikely to me.

Likewise Open Lock can potentially be reduced to if the Knock spell is easily obtainable and many locks can be opened with this spell with Take 20 you add +20 to your open lock score to unlock things, so Open Lock 20 modified = can open DC 40 locks etc etc. Need to know the environment if this is a potential option.

Anyway these suggestions *might* could give you the desired skill points for Listen or Spot without compromising on persuade. I think at least one detection skill is worthwhile for a sneaker, if you can detect them before they detect you it allows you to plan your next move proactively, rather than reacting to the enemy's attacks.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Well stick it in the multitude of skills to be permed from the 50 spare skill points I offer in my draft (about which some feedback would be appreciated, if only to say that it's not your thing).

You have to prioritize, because you will never have everything. You need the stealth skills. Tumble's AC bonus speaks for itself. Fairly crappy saves mean Spellcraft is essential to protect you as far as possible from casters. And UMD gives you access to scrolls, wands, and gear you wouldn't otherwise be able to use. If you don't know where your enemy is, then you're screwed, so you need at least one detection skill. That leaves points to distribute between "nice" things. You want to discover and disable traps (recovering them if possible), so you don't get bits of you blown off. Good. So that's some Search and Disable Traps. You haven't the strength to bash locks, but you probably want to get inside chests, so Open Locks also gets a tick (and don't forget about using Lock Picks to help you). So at the bottom of this pile are Set Trap (unless you want a very different type of build) and Persuade - regardless of what Rogueknight (the author) says. Apart from anything else, he's not going to invest all his time and effort into a set of modules that rely on a winning smile.

Think about your priorities. What my draft tries to do is cover your arse for the first 2 levels - that's all defence. Then it's getting the basics of combat abilities up to speed. Then you blossom into dual-wielding - when you're capable of landing regular hits, not just attempts. The rest is pretty colours, except for ED, which is a Dexer's nirvana.

Anyway, go and have a mull.

Cheers

EDIT: Ninja'd by Orion (for which my thanks), but I'll let it stand.
